items.title: Nvidia to ship H200 AI chips to China pending Beijing approval

featured_image.name: ByteDance and Alibaba want Nvidia H200 chips after green light

items.description:
Nvidia has informed Chinese customers that it intends to begin deliveries of its H200 AI chips before the Lunar New Year in mid-February, pending government approval from Beijing, according to three sources familiar with the matter who spoke to Reuters[1][2][3][4].

The American chipmaker plans to fulfill initial orders from existing inventory, with expected shipments ranging from 5,000 to 10,000 chip modules—equivalent to approximately 40,000 to 80,000 H200 AI chips, the sources said[1][2][3]. The company has also indicated it aims to expand production capacity for these chips, with new orders anticipated to open in the second quarter of 2026[1][2][3].

However, considerable uncertainty remains, as Beijing has not yet authorized any purchases of the H200 chips[1][2][3]. "The entire plan is reliant on government approval," one source told Reuters[1][2]. "Nothing is guaranteed until we receive the official green light."

items.title: New simulations and JWST reveal black hole mysteries

featured_image.name: Interstellar's fake black holes are helping actual ...

items.description:
Astronomers have unveiled two breakthroughs that deepen understanding of how black holes behave in extreme environments, with findings reported this week revealing both the most accurate simulations of black hole behavior ever created and mounting evidence for an exotic new class of cosmic objects powered by black holes in the early universe.

A study published December 3 in The Astrophysical Journal presents the first simulations to successfully model luminous black hole accretion without simplifying assumptions, using the world's most powerful supercomputers to solve Einstein's equations of general relativity while fully accounting for radiation[1][2][3]. Meanwhile, observations from the James Webb Space Telescope suggest that mysterious "little red dots" discovered in the distant universe are actually "black hole stars"—supermassive black holes wrapped in dense gas envelopes that glow like giant stars—according to analysis published today in New Scientist[4].

items.title: Scientists boost perovskite solar cell durability in extreme heat

featured_image.name: Perovskite solar cells retain 90% output after 1,500 hours ...

items.description:
Researchers at Purdue and Emory Universities have developed a method to dramatically improve the durability of perovskite solar cells, addressing one of the most stubborn barriers to commercializing this next-generation renewable energy technology.

The team engineered a specialized ionic liquid that enables perovskite solar cells to retain 90 percent of their performance after 1,500 hours of continuous operation at 90 degrees Celsius under full sunlight conditions, according to findings published in Nature Energy in December 2025[1][2][3]. The cells achieved a power conversion efficiency of 25.9 percent while demonstrating operational resilience that surpasses previous benchmarks tested under milder conditions[2][3].

items.title: Swiss court admits climate case against cement giant Holcim

featured_image.name: Swiss court to hear landmark climate case against cement ...

items.description:
A Swiss court has agreed to hear a pioneering climate lawsuit brought by Indonesian islanders against cement giant Holcim, marking the first time climate litigation against a major corporation has been admitted in Switzerland[1][2][3]. The Cantonal Court of Zug accepted the complaint in its entirety on Monday, allowing four residents of the low-lying island of Pari to pursue compensation and emissions reductions from the world's largest cement manufacturer[1][4].

The decision represents a significant legal milestone, granting standing to plaintiffs from a developing nation to sue a Swiss corporation for climate damages in Swiss courts[1][5]. Holcim, headquartered in Zug, has indicated it will appeal the ruling[2][5].

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia to resume ceasefire talks Dec. 24

featured_image.name: Thailand and Cambodia agree to stop border clashes, Trump says

items.description:
Thailand and Cambodia announced plans to meet December 24 to restart ceasefire negotiations, marking the first diplomatic breakthrough since deadly border clashes erupted two weeks ago and displaced more than half a million people.

Thai Foreign Minister Sihasak Phuangketkeow said officials from both nations would convene for bilateral discussions after attending a special Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) meeting in Kuala Lumpur on Monday[1][2]. According to Reuters, he welcomed the resumption of discussions on a ceasefire[2][3], offering a glimmer of hope as the conflict entered its 15th day.

The announcement came as foreign ministers from ASEAN's 11 member states gathered in Malaysia's capital for emergency talks aimed at salvaging a peace agreement that collapsed in November[4][5]. Monday's session marked the first face-to-face meeting between Thai and Cambodian government representatives since fighting resumed December 8 along their disputed 817-kilometer border[6][7].

items.title: Russia developing weapon to target Starlink with shrapnel clouds

featured_image.name: Russia launches 'space weapon' in path of US satellite: Pentagon

items.description: Western intelligence services believe Russia is developing a novel anti-satellite weapon designed to cripple Elon Musk’s Starlink internet constellation by seeding its orbital paths with dense clouds of shrapnel-like pellets, a move that could upend the safety of low-Earth orbit for all spacefaring nations.[1][2][3] The still-unproven system, described in classified findings shared with the Associated Press, would aim to disrupt the satellite backbone that has underpinned Ukraine’s battlefield communications since the early days of the war.[1][2][4]

items.title: Gold, silver hit records as Fed rate cut bets build

featured_image.name: Gold retreats as traders see slower Fed rate cuts in 2025 ...

items.description: Gold and silver powered to fresh all‑time highs on Monday, capping a blistering year‑end rally as investors doubled down on bets that the U.S. Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again after last week’s quarter‑point reduction. Spot gold climbed to around $$4,384$$ dollars an ounce, while silver vaulted toward the high‑60s per ounce, both extending steep year‑to‑date gains driven by safe‑haven demand, a softer dollar and persistent geopolitical tensions.[1][2][3]

items.title: Google slows Gemini shift as Samsung unveils AI fridge

featured_image.name: Samsung To Unveil AI Vision Built With Google Gemini at CES 2026

items.description:
Google has pushed back its plan to replace Google Assistant with Gemini on Android devices, extending the transition into 2026, the company announced Friday. The delay comes just days after Samsung revealed it will showcase the first home appliances powered by Google's Gemini AI at CES 2026 next month[1][2][3].

The tech giant originally planned to complete the Assistant-to-Gemini migration by the end of 2025, a timeline announced in March. "We're adjusting our previously announced timeline to make sure we deliver a seamless transition," Google stated in a community post, adding that the company will "continue our work to upgrade Assistant users to Gemini on mobile devices into 2026"[1][4][3].

items.title: Ex-Tesla executive Anderson emerges as top GM CEO candidate

featured_image.name: GM's Mary Barra Gauges Sterling Anderson for CEO Job by ...

items.description:
Sterling Anderson, General Motors' chief product officer, is emerging as the frontrunner to eventually succeed CEO Mary Barra when the 63-year-old retires, according to a Bloomberg report[1]. The development marks a significant moment in the succession planning for one of America's largest automakers.

Anderson joined GM in June after working at Tesla and co-founding autonomous trucking company Aurora Innovation[2][3]. The understanding when he was hired was that successfully advancing Barra's push to bring cutting-edge software and self-driving technology to GM vehicles could position him as a potential successor[1][3], people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg.

items.title: ASEAN convenes emergency talks on deadly Thailand-Cambodia clashes

featured_image.name: What's in the Thai-Cambodia peace agreement and can it hold?

items.description:
Southeast Asian foreign ministers gather in Kuala Lumpur on Monday for emergency talks aimed at halting deadly border clashes between Thailand and Cambodia that have killed at least 41 people and displaced more than 900,000 civilians since early December[1][2][1].

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim conducted telephone diplomacy with both Thai Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul and Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet on Sunday, urging the neighboring nations to "uphold the spirit of dialogue, wisdom and mutual respect" ahead of the special Association of Southeast Asian Nations meeting[1][3][4]. The talks, to be chaired by Malaysian Foreign Minister Mohamad Hasan, represent the first face-to-face diplomatic engagement between the governments since fighting reignited on December 7[5][5].

items.title: Japan to restart world's largest nuclear plant

featured_image.name: Japan's Biggest Nuclear Plant in Niigata to Get De Facto ...

items.description: The Niigata prefectural assembly is poised to endorse the restart of the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant as early as this week, clearing the final political hurdle for the world’s largest nuclear facility to return to operation nearly 15 years after the Fukushima disaster.[1][2][3] The move caps a months-long push by Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings Inc. (TEPCO) and the central government to rebuild Japan’s nuclear fleet amid rising energy demand and high fossil fuel costs.[1][2][4]

items.title: Starmer, Trump discuss Ukraine peace talks in pre-Christmas call

featured_image.name: UK Premier Starmer discusses Ukraine peace efforts with Trump

items.description:
British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and US President Donald Trump spoke Sunday in what is likely their final call of 2025, discussing efforts to secure a lasting end to the war in Ukraine and the fragile humanitarian situation in Gaza. The conversation came as US-led peace negotiations in Florida showed signs of progress, with both Ukrainian and Russian officials describing recent talks as "constructive."[1][2][3]

According to Downing Street, the leaders "began by reflecting on the war in Ukraine," with Starmer updating Trump on the work of the Coalition of the Willing to support any peace deal and ensure a lasting end to hostilities.[4][5][6] The call took place as Trump spoke from his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.[5][7]
